thread.title: Lincoln's fans proved FA Cup magic is still alive - but Arsene Wenger couldn't afford to indulge them
thread.title_full: Lincoln's fans proved FA Cup magic is still alive - but Arsene Wenger couldn't afford to indulge them

author: Neil Moxley
title: Lincoln's fans proved FA Cup magic is still alive - but Arsene Wenger couldn't afford to indulge them
text:
Arsene Wenger's Arsenal crushed Lincoln's FA Cup dreams (Photo: Arsenal FC) Share Get Arsenal FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The romance in this year’s FA Cup was alive and kicking at the Clock End of the Emirates Stadium. 
Nine thousand fans from Lincolnshire sang their songs, waved their banners and generally had a blast. 
If you are going to enjoy a day to remember then you have to create it. 
And boy, did the Impvasion go with a swing. 
For while the FA are under pressure to reinvent the world’s most famous knockout competition, there is clearly life in the old girl yet, judging by the antics in the away end. Lincoln's fans showed the romance of the FA Cup lives on (Photo: PA) 
The importance of these fantastic dates on football’s calendar has been lost on many of the glitterati. 
Weakened teams, dwindling attendances and falling interest among supporters, it’s importance has been diluted. 
This year, the powers-that-be decided to dispense with replays at the last-eight stage. Teams can now make four substitutions if the match goes into extra time. 
But the FA Cup did not need any artificial stimulation, and Lincoln’s fans did not need any viagra from the authorities to get themselves up for this. 
However, that’s where the story had to end. Arsenal were 5-0 victors over their non-league opponents (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Arsene Wenger could not buy into the dream. He just could not afford to. 
From the moment the Frenchman handed in his team-sheet to match official Anthony Taylor – the pair came face-to-face for the first time professionally since Arsenal’s boss shoved the referee in the tunnel two months ago – any such notion had to be stamped upon. 
There was no dewy-eyed sentimentality as far as Wenger was concerned. 
It was kill or be killed. Arsene Wenger surely couldn't have survived a home loss to Lincoln (Photo: AFP) 
If Lincoln City, yes Lincoln City, had broken open their tool box and hammered home a nail, then it would have been the final one in Wenger’s coffin. 
Arsenal’s punters would not have known whether to laugh or cry. The humiliation of being a national embarrassment for a few days would, possibly, have been outweighed by the fact that the 20-year reign – that has hung like a lead weight around Wenger’s neck these past few months – would have finally dragged him under.
